SENT.plain: In five head-injured patients with cerebral contusion and oedema in whom it was not possible to control ICP by hyperventilation and barbiturate sedation, indomethacin Confortid was used as a cerebral vasoconstrictor drug
In all patients indomethacin reduced ICP below 20 mmHg for several hours
Studies of cerebral circulation and metabolism during indomethacin treatment showed a decrease in cerebral blood flow (CBF) at 2 hours
ICP remained below 20 mmHg in three patients, and these still had reduced CBF
In two patients a return of ICP and CBF to pretreatment levels was observed
In all patients indomethacin treatment was followed by a fall in rectal temperature
Outcome scaling has not yet been performed, but all patients left hospital without neurological deficits
These results suggest that indomethacin is an alternative in the treatment of intracranial hypertension in head-injured patients
